command.name: about
command.help:
The about command displays information about the current Symfony project.

The PHP section displays important configuration that could affect your application. The values might
be different between web and CLI.

Options:
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: help
command.help:
The help command displays help for a given command:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console help list

You can also output the help in other formats by using the --format option:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console help --format=xml list

To display the list of available commands, please use the list command.

command.name: list
command.help:
The list command lists all commands:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console list

You can also display the commands for a specific namespace:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console list test

You can also output the information in other formats by using the --format option:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console list --format=xml

It's also possible to get raw list of commands (useful for embedding command runner):

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console list --raw

Options:
--rawTo output raw command list
--formatThe output format (txt, xml, json, or md)
--shortTo skip describing commands' arguments
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command

--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: assets:install
command.help:
The assets:install command installs bundle assets into a given
directory (e.g. the public directory).

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console assets:install public

A "bundles" directory will be created inside the target directory and the
"Resources/public" directory of each bundle will be copied into it.

To create a symlink to each bundle instead of copying its assets, use the
--symlink option (will fall back to hard copies when symbolic links aren't possible:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console assets:install public --symlink

To make symlink relative, add the --relative option:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console assets:install public --symlink --relative


Options:
--symlinkSymlink the assets instead of copying them
--relativeMake relative symlinks
--no-cleanupDo not remove the assets of the bundles that no longer exist
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: cache:clear
command.help:

and debug mode:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console cache:clear --env=dev

command.name: cache:warmup
command.help:
The cache:warmup command warms up the cache.

Before running this command, the cache must be empty.

This command does not generate the classes cache (as when executing this
command, too many classes that should be part of the cache are already loaded
in memory). Use curl or any other similar tool to warm up
the classes cache if you want.

command.name: config:dump-reference
command.help:
The config:dump-reference command dumps the default configuration for an
extension/bundle.

Either the extension alias or bundle name can be used:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console config:dump-reference framework
php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console config:dump-reference FrameworkBundle

With the --format option specifies the format of the configuration,
this is either yaml or xml.
When the option is not provided, yaml is used.

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console config:dump-reference FrameworkBundle --format=xml

For dumping a specific option, add its path as second argument (only available for the yaml format):

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console config:dump-reference framework profiler.matcher

--formatThe output format (yaml or xml)
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used

command.name: debug:container
command.help:
The debug:container command displays all configured public services:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:container

To see deprecations generated during container compilation and cache warmup, use the --deprecations option:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:container --deprecations

To get specific information about a service, specify its name:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:container validator

To get specific information about a service including all its arguments, use the --show-arguments flag:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:container validator --show-arguments

To see available types that can be used for autowiring, use the --types flag:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:container --types

To see environment variables used by the container, use the --env-vars flag:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:container --env-vars

Display a specific environment variable by specifying its name with the --env-var option:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:container --env-var=APP_ENV

Use the --tags option to display tagged public services grouped by tag:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:container --tags

Find all services with a specific tag by specifying the tag name with the --tag option:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:container --tag=form.type

Use the --parameters option to display all parameters:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:container --parameters

Display a specific parameter by specifying its name with the --parameter option:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:container --parameter=kernel.debug

By default, internal services are hidden. You can display them
using the --show-hidden flag:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:container --show-hidden


Options:
--show-argumentsShow arguments in services
--show-hiddenShow hidden (internal) services
--tagShow all services with a specific tag
--tagsDisplay tagged services for an application
--parameterDisplay a specific parameter for an application

command.name: debug:firewall
command.help:
The debug:firewall command displays the firewalls that are configured
in your application:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:firewall

You can pass a firewall name to display more detailed information about
a specific firewall:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:firewall main

To include all events and event listeners for a specific firewall, use the
events option:

command.name: debug:form
command.help:
The debug:form command displays information about form types.

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:form

The command lists all built-in types, services types, type extensions and
guessers currently available.

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:form Symfony\Component\Form\Extension\Core\Type\ChoiceType
php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:form ChoiceType

The command lists all defined options that contains the given form type,
as well as their parents and type extensions.

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:form ChoiceType choice_value

Use the --show-deprecated option to display form types with
deprecated options or the deprecated options of the given form type:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:form --show-deprecated
php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:form ChoiceType --show-deprecated

The command displays the definition of the given option name.

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:form --format=json

The command lists everything in a machine readable json format.

command.name: debug:translation
command.help:
The debug:translation command helps finding unused or missing translation
messages and comparing them with the fallback ones by inspecting the
templates and translation files of a given bundle or the default translations directory.

You can display information about bundle translations in a specific locale:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:translation en AcmeDemoBundle

You can also specify a translation domain for the search:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:translation --domain=messages en AcmeDemoBundle

You can only display missing messages:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:translation --only-missing en AcmeDemoBundle

You can only display unused messages:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:translation --only-unused en AcmeDemoBundle

You can display information about application translations in a specific locale:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:translation en

You can display information about translations in all registered bundles in a specific locale:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console debug:translation --all en


Options:
--domainThe messages domain
--only-missingDisplay only missing messages
--only-unusedDisplay only unused messages
--allLoad messages from all registered bundles

command.name: doctrine:cache:clear-collection-region
command.help:
The doctrine:cache:clear-collection-region command is meant to clear a second-level cache collection regions for an associated Entity Manager.
It is possible to delete/invalidate all collection region, a specific collection region or flushes the cache provider.

The execution type differ on how you execute the command.
If you want to invalidate all entries for an collection region this command would do the work:

doctrine:cache:clear-collection-region 'Entities\MyEntity' 'collectionName'

To invalidate a specific entry you should use :

doctrine:cache:clear-collection-region 'Entities\MyEntity' 'collectionName' 1

If you want to invalidate all entries for the all collection regions:

doctrine:cache:clear-collection-region --all

Alternatively, if you want to flush the configured cache provider for an collection region use this command:

doctrine:cache:clear-collection-region 'Entities\MyEntity' 'collectionName' --flush

Finally, be aware that if --flush option is passed,
not all cache providers are able to flush entries, because of a limitation of its execution nature.

Options:
--emName of the entity manager to operate on
--allIf defined, all entity regions will be deleted/invalidated.
--flushIf defined, all cache entries will be flushed.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: doctrine:cache:clear-query
command.help:
The doctrine:cache:clear-query command is meant to clear the query cache of associated Entity Manager.
It is possible to invalidate all cache entries at once - called delete -, or flushes the cache provider
instance completely.

The execution type differ on how you execute the command.
If you want to invalidate the entries (and not delete from cache instance), this command would do the work:

doctrine:cache:clear-query

Alternatively, if you want to flush the cache provider using this command:

doctrine:cache:clear-query --flush

Finally, be aware that if --flush option is passed, not all cache providers are able to flush entries,
because of a limitation of its execution nature.

doctrine:cache:clear-query-region --all

Alternatively, if you want to flush the configured cache provider use this command:

doctrine:cache:clear-query-region my_region_name --flush

Finally, be aware that if --flush option is passed,
not all cache providers are able to flush entries, because of a limitation of its execution nature.

command.name: doctrine:database:drop
command.help:
The doctrine:database:drop command drops the default connections database:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:database:drop

The --force parameter has to be used to actually drop the database.

You can also optionally specify the name of a connection to drop the database for:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:database:drop --connection=default

Be careful: All data in a given database will be lost when executing this command.

command.name: doctrine:mapping:convert
command.help:
Convert mapping information between supported formats.

This is an execute one-time command. It should not be necessary for
you to call this method multiple times, especially when using the --from-database
flag.

Converting an existing database schema into mapping files only solves about 70-80%
of the necessary mapping information. Additionally the detection from an existing
database cannot detect inverse associations, inheritance types,
entities with foreign keys as primary keys and many of the
semantical operations on associations such as cascade.

Hint: There is no need to convert YAML or XML mapping files to annotations
every time you make changes. All mapping drivers are first class citizens
in Doctrine 2 and can be used as runtime mapping for the ORM.

Hint: If you have a database with tables that should not be managed
by the ORM, you can use a DBAL functionality to filter the tables and sequences down
on a global level:

$config->setFilterSchemaAssetsExpression($regexp);

Options:
--emName of the entity manager to operate on
--filterA string pattern used to match entities that should be processed.
--force(-f)Force to overwrite existing mapping files.
--from-databaseWhether or not to convert mapping information from existing database.
--extendDefines a base class to be extended by generated entity classes.
--num-spacesDefines the number of indentation spaces
--namespaceDefines a namespace for the generated entity classes, if converted from database.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: doctrine:mapping:import
command.help:
The doctrine:mapping:import command imports mapping information
from an existing database:

Generate annotation mappings into the src/ directory using App as the namespace:
php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:mapping:import App\\Entity annotation --path=src/Entity

Generate xml mappings into the config/doctrine/ directory using App as the namespace:
php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:mapping:import App\\Entity xml --path=config/doctrine

Generate XML mappings into a bundle:
php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:mapping:import "MyCustomBundle" xml

You can also optionally specify which entity manager to import from with the
--em option:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:mapping:import "MyCustomBundle" xml --em=default

If you don't want to map every entity that can be found in the database, use the
--filter option. It will try to match the targeted mapped entity with the
provided pattern string.

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:mapping:import "MyCustomBundle" xml --filter=MyMatchedEntity

Use the --force option, if you want to override existing mapping files:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:mapping:import "MyCustomBundle" xml --force

Options:
--emThe entity manager to use for this command
--shardThe shard connection to use for this command
--filterA string pattern used to match entities that should be mapped.
--forceForce to overwrite existing mapping files.
--pathThe path where the files would be generated (not used when a bundle is passed).
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: doctrine:migrations:execute
command.help:
The doctrine:migrations:execute command executes migration versions up or down manually:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:execute FQCN

You can show more information about the process by increasing the verbosity level. To see the
executed queries, set the level to debug with -vv:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:execute FQCN -vv

If no --up or --down option is specified it defaults to up:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:execute FQCN --down

You can also execute the migration as a --dry-run:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:execute FQCN --dry-run

You can output the prepared SQL statements to a file with --write-sql:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:execute FQCN --write-sql

Or you can also execute the migration without a warning message which you need to interact with:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:execute FQCN --no-interaction

All the previous commands accept multiple migration versions, allowing you run execute more than
one migration at once:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:execute FQCN-1 FQCN-2 ...FQCN-n


Options:
--write-sqlThe path to output the migration SQL file. Defaults to current working directory.
--dry-runExecute the migration as a dry run.
--upExecute the migration up.
--downExecute the migration down.
--query-timeTime all the queries individually.
--configurationThe path to a migrations configuration file. [default: any of migrations.{php,xml,json,yml,yaml}]
--emThe name of the entity manager to use.
--connThe name of the connection to use.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: doctrine:migrations:migrate
command.help:
The doctrine:migrations:migrate command executes a migration to a specified version or the latest available version:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:migrate

You can show more information about the process by increasing the verbosity level. To see the
executed queries, set the level to debug with -vv:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:migrate -vv

You can optionally manually specify the version you wish to migrate to:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:migrate FQCN

You can specify the version you wish to migrate to using an alias:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:migrate prev
These alias are defined : first, latest, prev, current and next

You can specify the version you wish to migrate to using an number against the current version:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:migrate current+3

You can also execute the migration as a --dry-run:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:migrate FQCN --dry-run

You can output the prepared SQL statements to a file with --write-sql:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:migrate FQCN --write-sql

Or you can also execute the migration without a warning message which you need to interact with:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:migrate --no-interaction

You can also time all the different queries if you wanna know which one is taking so long:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:migrate --query-time

Use the --all-or-nothing option to wrap the entire migration in a transaction.


Options:
--write-sqlThe path to output the migration SQL file. Defaults to current working directory.
--dry-runExecute the migration as a dry run.
--query-timeTime all the queries individually.
--allow-no-migrationDo not throw an exception if no migration is available.
--all-or-nothingWrap the entire migration in a transaction.
--configurationThe path to a migrations configuration file. [default: any of migrations.{php,xml,json,yml,yaml}]
--emThe name of the entity manager to use.
--connThe name of the connection to use.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: doctrine:migrations:rollup
command.help:
The doctrine:migrations:rollup command rolls up migrations by deleting all tracked versions and
inserts the one version that exists that was created with the migrations:dump-schema command.

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:rollup

To dump your schema to a migration version you can use the migrations:dump-schema command.

command.name: doctrine:migrations:version
command.help:
The doctrine:migrations:version command allows you to manually add, delete or synchronize migration versions from the version table:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:version MIGRATION-FQCN --add

If you want to delete a version you can use the --delete option:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:version MIGRATION-FQCN --delete

If you want to synchronize by adding or deleting all migration versions available in the version table you can use the --all option:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:version --add --all
/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:version --delete --all

If you want to synchronize by adding or deleting some range of migration versions available in the version table you can use the --range-from/--range-to option:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:version --add --range-from=MIGRATION-FQCN --range-to=MIGRATION-FQCN
/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:version --delete --range-from=MIGRATION-FQCN --range-to=MIGRATION-FQCN

You can also execute this command without a warning message which you need to interact with:

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:migrations:version --no-interaction

Options:
--addAdd the specified version.
--deleteDelete the specified version.
--allApply to all the versions.
--range-fromApply from specified version.
--range-toApply to specified version.
--configurationThe path to a migrations configuration file. [default: any of migrations.{php,xml,json,yml,yaml}]
--emThe name of the entity manager to use.
--connThe name of the connection to use.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: doctrine:query:dql
command.help:
The doctrine:query:dql command executes the given DQL query and
outputs the results:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:query:dql "SELECT u FROM UserBundle:User u"

You can also optional specify some additional options like what type of
hydration to use when executing the query:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:query:dql "SELECT u FROM UserBundle:User u" --hydrate=array

Additionally you can specify the first result and maximum amount of results to
show:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console doctrine:query:dql "SELECT u FROM UserBundle:User u" --first-result=0 --max-result=30

Options:
--emName of the entity manager to operate on
--hydrateHydration mode of result set. Should be either: object, array, scalar or single-scalar.
--first-resultThe first result in the result set.
--max-resultThe maximum number of results in the result set.
--depthDumping depth of Entity graph.
--show-sqlDump generated SQL instead of executing query
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version

--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question

--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: doctrine:schema:update
command.help:
The doctrine:schema:update command generates the SQL needed to
synchronize the database schema with the current mapping metadata of the
default entity manager.

For example, if you add metadata for a new column to an entity, this command
would generate and output the SQL needed to add the new column to the database:

doctrine:schema:update --dump-sql

Alternatively, you can execute the generated queries:

doctrine:schema:update --force

If both options are specified, the queries are output and then executed:

doctrine:schema:update --dump-sql --force

Finally, be aware that if the --complete option is passed, this
task will drop all database assets (e.g. tables, etc) that are *not* described
by the current metadata. In other words, without this option, this task leaves
untouched any "extra" tables that exist in the database, but which aren't
described by any metadata.

Hint: If you have a database with tables that should not be managed
by the ORM, you can use a DBAL functionality to filter the tables and sequences down
on a global level:

$config->setFilterSchemaAssetsExpression($regexp);

Options:
--emName of the entity manager to operate on
--completeIf defined, all assets of the database which are not relevant to the current metadata will be dropped.
--dump-sqlDumps the generated SQL statements to the screen (does not execute them).
--force(-f)Causes the generated SQL statements to be physically executed against your database.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: ibexa:commerce:switch-data-provider
command.help:
This command will switch to the specified data provider.

Current supported data providers are:
- ez (for Ibexa Repository)
- econtent

Examples to switch to econtent:
--------------------------------
You have to specify the location id of the product catalog and the location id of the root element.

silversolutions:switchdataprovider econtent --location-id=86 --new-root-node=12
silversolutions:switchdataprovider econtent --location-id=11912 --new-root-node=13
silversolutions:switchdataprovider econtent --location-id=11913 --new-root-node=11

Example to switch to ez (Ibexa Repository):
-------------------------------
You dont have to specify the location ids of your product catalogs. The script will iterate over all defined product catalogs and specify their location id as a root node.

silversolutions:switchdataprovider ez


Options:
--location-id(-l)Specifies the location id of product catalog. If its not set all available product catalogs will be updated
--new-root-node(-r)
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: ibexa:content:cleanup-versions
command.help:
The command ibexa:content:cleanup-versions reduces content versions to a minimum.
It keeps published version untouched, and by default also keeps the last archived/draft version.
Note: This script can potentially run for a very long time, and in Symfony dev environment it will consume memory exponentially with the size of the dataset.

Before you continue:
- Make sure to back up your database.
- Take the installation offline. The database should not be modified while the script is being executed.
- Run this command without memory limit.
- Run this command in production environment using --env=prod

Options:
--status(-t)Select which version types should be removed: 'draft', 'archived', 'all'.
--keep(-k)Sets the number of the most recent versions (both drafts and archived) which won't be removed.
--user(-u)eZ Platform username (with Role containing at least content policies: remove, read, versionread)
--excluded-content-typesComma-separated list of Content Type identifiers whose versions should not be removed, for instance `article`.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

option.name: --status
option.help: Select which version types should be removed: 'draft', 'archived', 'all'.

option.name: --keep
option.help: Sets the number of the most recent versions (both drafts and archived) which won't be removed.

option.name: --user
option.help: eZ Platform username (with Role containing at least content policies: remove, read, versionread)

option.name: --excluded-content-types
option.help: Comma-separated list of Content Type identifiers whose versions should not be removed, for instance `article`.

command.name: ibexa:debug:config-resolver
command.help:
Outputs a given config resolver parameter, more commonly known as a SiteAccess setting.

By default it will give value depending on the global --siteaccess[=SITEACCESS] (default SiteAccess is used if not set).

However, you can also manually set --scope[=NAME] yourself if you don't want to affect the SiteAccess
set by the system. You can also override the namespace to get something other than the default "ezsettings" namespace by using
the --namespace[=NS] option.

NOTE: To see *all* compiled SiteAccess settings, use: debug:config ezpublish [system.default]


Options:
--jsonOnly return value, for automation / testing use on a single line in json format.
--scopeSet another scope (SiteAccess) to use. This is an alternative to using the global --siteaccess[=SITEACCESS] option.
--namespaceSet a different namespace than the default "ezsettings" used by SiteAccess settings.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

option.name: --json
option.help: Only return value, for automation / testing use on a single line in json format.

option.name: --scope
option.help: Set another scope (SiteAccess) to use. This is an alternative to using the global --siteaccess[=SITEACCESS] option.

option.name: --namespace
option.help: Set a different namespace than the default "ezsettings" used by SiteAccess settings.

command.name: ibexa:io:migrate-files
command.help:
The command ibexa:io:migrate-files migrates files from one IO repository
to another. It can for example be used to migrate local files from the default
IO configuration to a new IO configuration, such as a clustered setup.

Note: This command is experimental. Use with caution!

The --from and --to values must be specified as ,.
If --from is omitted, the default IO configuration will be used.
If --to is omitted, the first non-default IO configuration will be used.

The database should not be modified while the script is being executed.
You are advised to create a backup or execute a dry run before
proceeding with the actual update.

Since this script can potentially run for a very long time, to avoid memory
exhaustion run it in production environment using --env=prod switch.

--fromMigrate from ,
--toMigrate to ,
--list-io-handlersList available IO handlers

command.name: ibexa:reindex
command.help:
The command ibexa:reindex indexes the current configured database in the configured search engine index.


Example usage:
- Refresh (add/update) index changes since yesterday:
ibexa:reindex --since=yesterday
See: http://php.net/manual/en/datetime.formats.php

- Refresh (add/update/remove) index on a set of content ID's:
ibexa:reindex --content-ids=2,34,68

- Refresh (add/update) index of a subtree:
ibexa:reindex --subtree=45

- Refresh (add/update) index, disabling the use of child proccesses and initial purging,
and let search engine handle commits using auto commit:
ibexa:reindex --no-purge --no-commit --processes=0


Options:
--iteration-count(-c)Number of objects to be indexed in a single iteration set to avoid using too much memory
--no-commitDo not commit after each iteration
--no-purgeDo not purge before indexing
--sinceRefresh changes since a time provided in any format understood by DateTime. Implies "no-purge", cannot be combined with "content-ids" or "subtree"
--content-idsComma-separated list of content ID's to refresh (deleted/updated/added). Implies "no-purge", cannot be combined with "since" or "subtree"
--subtreeLocation ID whose subtree will be indexed (including the Location itself). Implies "no-purge", cannot be combined with "since" or "content-ids"
--processesNumber of child processes to run in parallel for iterations, if set to "auto" it will set to number of CPU cores -1, set to "1" or "0" to disable
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

option.name: --iteration-count
option.help: Number of objects to be indexed in a single iteration set to avoid using too much memory

option.name: --no-commit
option.help: Do not commit after each iteration

option.name: --since
option.help: Refresh changes since a time provided in any format understood by DateTime. Implies "no-purge", cannot be combined with "content-ids" or "subtree"

option.name: --content-ids
option.help: Comma-separated list of content ID's to refresh (deleted/updated/added). Implies "no-purge", cannot be combined with "since" or "subtree"

option.name: --subtree
option.help: Location ID whose subtree will be indexed (including the Location itself). Implies "no-purge", cannot be combined with "since" or "content-ids"

option.help: Number of child processes to run in parallel for iterations, if set to "auto" it will set to number of CPU cores -1, set to "1" or "0" to disable

command.name: ibexa:timestamps:to-utc
command.help:
The command ibexa:timestamps:to-utc updates field
data_int in configured Legacy Storage database for a given Field Type.

This is to be used either when migrating from eZ Publish to eZ Platform
(when using platform backend instead of legacy), or when upgrading legacy
to v2019.03 which has been adapted to use UTC.

The database should not be modified while the script is being executed.

You are advised to create a backup or execute a dry run before
proceeding with the actual update.

This command should only be ran ONCE.

Since this script can potentially run for a very long time, to avoid memory
exhaustion run it in production environment using --env=prod switch.

Options:
--dry-runExecute a dry run
--modeSelect conversion scope: date, datetime, all
--fromOnly versions AFTER this date will be converted

command.name: ibexa:urls:regenerate-aliases
command.help:
Before you continue:
- Make sure to back up your database.
- If you are regenerating URL aliases for all Locations, take the installation offline. The database should not be modified while the script is being executed.
- Run this command without memory limit, because processing large numbers of Locations (e.g. 300k) can take up to 1 GB of RAM.
- Run this command in production environment using --env=prod
- Manually clear HTTP cache after running this command.

The command ibexa:urls:regenerate-aliases regenerates URL aliases for Locations and cleans up
corrupted URL aliases (pointing to non-existent Locations).
Existing aliases are archived (will redirect to the new ones).

Note: This script can potentially run for a very long time.

Due to performance issues the command does not send any Events.

You need to clear HTTP cache manually after executing this command.

command.name: liip:imagine:cache:remove
command.help:
The liip:imagine:cache:remove command removes the passed image(s) cache entry for the
resolved filter(s), outputting results using the following basic format:
image.ext[filter] (removed|skipped|failure)[: (image-path|exception-message)]

# bin/console liip:imagine:cache:remove --filter=thumb1 foo.ext bar.ext
Remove cache for both foo.ext and bar.ext images for one filter (thumb1), outputting:
- foo.ext[thumb1] removed
- bar.ext[thumb1] removed

# bin/console liip:imagine:cache:remove --filter=thumb1 --filter=thumb3 foo.ext
Remove cache for foo.ext image using two filters (thumb1 and thumb3), outputting:
- foo.ext[thumb1] removed
- foo.ext[thumb3] removed

# bin/console liip:imagine:cache:remove foo.ext
Remove cache for foo.ext image using all filters (as none were specified), outputting:
- foo.ext[thumb1] removed
- foo.ext[thumb2] removed
- foo.ext[thumb3] removed


Options:
--filter(-f)Filter(s) to use for image remove; if none explicitly passed, use all filters.
--no-colors(-C)Write only un-styled text output; remove any colors, styling, etc.
--as-script(-S)Write only machine-readable output; silenced verbose reporting and implies --no-colors.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: liip:imagine:cache:resolve
command.help:
The liip:imagine:cache:resolve command resolves the passed image(s) for the resolved
filter(s), outputting results using the following basic format:
image.ext[filter] (resolved|cached|failed): (resolve-image-path|exception-message)

# bin/console liip:imagine:cache:resolve --filter=thumb1 foo.ext bar.ext
Resolve both foo.ext and bar.ext images using one filter (thumb1), outputting:
- foo.ext[thumb1] status: http://localhost/media/cache/thumb1/foo.ext
- bar.ext[thumb1] status: http://localhost/media/cache/thumb1/bar.ext

# bin/console liip:imagine:cache:resolve --filter=thumb1 --filter=thumb3 foo.ext
Resolve foo.ext image using two filters (thumb1 and thumb3), outputting:
- foo.ext[thumb1] status: http://localhost/media/cache/thumb1/foo.ext
- foo.ext[thumb3] status: http://localhost/media/cache/thumb3/foo.ext

# bin/console liip:imagine:cache:resolve foo.ext
Resolve foo.ext image using all filters (as none were specified), outputting:
- foo.ext[thumb1] status: http://localhost/media/cache/thumb1/foo.ext
- foo.ext[thumb2] status: http://localhost/media/cache/thumb2/foo.ext
- foo.ext[thumb3] status: http://localhost/media/cache/thumb2/foo.ext

# bin/console liip:imagine:cache:resolve --force --filter=thumb1 foo.ext
Resolve foo.ext image using one filter (thumb1) and forcing resolution (regardless of cache), outputting:
- foo.ext[thumb1] resolved: http://localhost/media/cache/thumb1/foo.ext


Options:
--filter(-f)Filter(s) to use for image resolution; if none explicitly passed, use all filters.
--force(-F)Force generating the image and writing the cache, regardless of whether a cached version already exists.
--no-colors(-C)Write only un-styled text output; remove any colors, styling, etc.
--as-script(-S)Write only machine-readable output; silenced verbose reporting and implies --no-colors.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

command.name: lint:twig
command.help:
The lint:twig command lints a template and outputs to STDOUT
the first encountered syntax error.

You can validate the syntax of contents passed from STDIN:

cat filename | php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console lint:twig -

Or the syntax of a file:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console lint:twig filename

Or of a whole directory:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console lint:twig dirname
php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console lint:twig dirname --format=json

Or all template files in a bundle:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console lint:twig @AcmeDemoBundle


Options:
--formatThe output format
--show-deprecationsShow deprecations as errors
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command

command.name: lint:xliff
command.help:
The lint:xliff command lints an XLIFF file and outputs to STDOUT
the first encountered syntax error.

You can validates XLIFF contents passed from STDIN:

cat filename | php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console lint:xliff -

You can also validate the syntax of a file:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console lint:xliff filename

Or of a whole directory:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console lint:xliff dirname
php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console lint:xliff dirname --format=json

command.name: make:auth
command.help:
The make:auth command generates various authentication systems,
by asking questions.

It can provide an empty authenticator, or a full login form authentication process.
In both cases it also updates your security.yaml.
For the login form, it also generates a controller and the twig template.

command.name: make:entity
command.help:
The make:entity command creates or updates an entity and repository class.

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console make:entity BlogPost

If the argument is missing, the command will ask for the entity class name interactively.

You can also mark this class as an API Platform resource. A hypermedia CRUD API will
automatically be available for this entity class:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console make:entity --api-resource

Symfony can also broadcast all changes made to the entity to the client using Symfony
UX Turbo.

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console make:entity --broadcast

You can also generate all the getter/setter/adder/remover methods
for the properties of existing entities:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console make:entity --regenerate

You can also *overwrite* any existing methods:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console make:entity --regenerate --overwrite


Options:
--api-resource(-a)Mark this class as an API Platform resource (expose a CRUD API for it)
--broadcast(-b)Add the ability to broadcast entity updates using Symfony UX Turbo?
--regenerateInstead of adding new fields, simply generate the methods (e.g. getter/setter) for existing fields
--overwriteOverwrite any existing getter/setter methods
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used

--version(-V)Display this application version

--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question

command.name: make:form
command.help:
The make:form command generates a new form class.

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console make:form UserType

If the argument is missing, the command will ask for the form class interactively.

You can optionally specify the bound class in a second argument.
This can be the name of an entity like User

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console make:form UserType User

You can also specify a fully qualified name to another class like \App\Dto\UserData.
Slashes must be escaped in the argument.

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console make:form UserType \\App\\Dto\\UserData

command.name: make:reset-password
command.help:
The make:reset-password command generates all the files needed to implement
a fully-functional & secure password reset system.

The SymfonycastsResetPasswordBundle is required and can be added using composer:
composer require symfonycasts/reset-password-bundle

For more information on the reset-password-bundle check out:
https://github.com/symfonycasts/reset-password-bundle

make:reset-password requires a user entity with an email property,
email getter method, and a password setter method. Maker will ask for these
interactively if they cannot be guessed.

Maker will also update your reset-password.yaml configuration file
if one exists. If you have customized the configuration file, maker will attempt
to modify it accordingly but preserve your customizations.

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console make:reset-password

command.name: make:test
command.help:
The make:test command generates a new test class.

* TestCase: basic PHPUnit tests
* KernelTestCase: basic tests that have access to Symfony services
* WebTestCase: to run browser-like scenarios, but that don't execute JavaScript code
* ApiTestCase: to run API-oriented scenarios
* PantherTestCase: to run e2e scenarios, using a real-browser or HTTP client and a real web server

command.name: secrets:set
command.help:
The secrets:set command stores a secret in the vault.

/home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console secrets:set

To reference secrets in services.yaml or any other config
files, use "%env()%".

By default, the secret value should be entered interactively.
Alternatively, provide a file where to read the secret from:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console secrets:set filename

Use "-" as a file name to read from STDIN:

cat filename | php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console secrets:set -

Use --local to override secrets for local needs.

command.name: security:encode-password
command.help:
The security:encode-password command encodes passwords according to your
security configuration. This command is mainly used to generate passwords for
the in_memory user provider type and for changing passwords
in the database while developing the application.

Suppose that you have the following security configuration in your application:


# app/config/security.yml
security:
encoders:
Symfony\Component\Security\Core\User\InMemoryUser: plaintext
App\Entity\User: auto


If you execute the command non-interactively, the first available configured
user class under the security.encoders key is used and a random salt is
generated to encode the password:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console security:encode-password --no-interaction [password]

Pass the full user class path as the second argument to encode passwords for
your own entities:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console security:encode-password --no-interaction [password] 'App\Entity\User'

Executing the command interactively allows you to generate a random salt for
encoding the password:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console security:encode-password [password] 'App\Entity\User'

In case your encoder doesn't require a salt, add the empty-salt option:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console security:encode-password --empty-salt [password] 'App\Entity\User'


Options:
--empty-saltDo not generate a salt or let the encoder generate one.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

option.name: --empty-salt
option.help: Do not generate a salt or let the encoder generate one.

command.name: security:hash-password
command.help:
The security:hash-password command hashes passwords according to your
security configuration. This command is mainly used to generate passwords for
the in_memory user provider type and for changing passwords
in the database while developing the application.

Suppose that you have the following security configuration in your application:


# app/config/security.yml
security:
password_hashers:
Symfony\Component\Security\Core\User\InMemoryUser: plaintext
App\Entity\User: auto


If you execute the command non-interactively, the first available configured
user class under the security.password_hashers key is used and a random salt is
generated to hash the password:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console security:hash-password --no-interaction [password]

Pass the full user class path as the second argument to hash passwords for
your own entities:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console security:hash-password --no-interaction [password] 'App\Entity\User'

Executing the command interactively allows you to generate a random salt for
hashing the password:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console security:hash-password [password] 'App\Entity\User'

In case your hasher doesn't require a salt, add the empty-salt option:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console security:hash-password --empty-salt [password] 'App\Entity\User'


Options:
--empty-saltDo not generate a salt or let the hasher generate one.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

--bundle(-b)The bundle that you want to extract translations for.
--exclude-nameA pattern which should be ignored, e.g. *Test.php
--exclude-dirA directory name which should be ignored, e.g. Tests
--ignore-domain(-i)A domain to ignore.
--domainUse only this domain.
--dir(-d)A directory to scan for messages.
--output-dirThe directory where files should be written to.
--dry-runWhen specified, changes are _NOT_ persisted to disk.
--output-formatThe output format that should be used (in most cases, it is better to change only the default-output-format).
--intl-icuFlag to indicate if translations should be dumped to using the ICU message format.
--default-output-formatThe default output format (defaults to xlf).
--keepDefine if the updater service should keep the old translation (defaults to false).
--external-translations-dirLoad external translation resources

command.name: translation:pull
command.help:
The translation:pull command pulls translations from the given provider. Only
new translations are pulled, existing ones are not overwritten.

You can overwrite existing translations (and remove the missing ones on local side) by using the --force flag:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console translation:pull --force provider

Full example:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console translation:pull provider --force --domains=messages,validators --locales=en

This command pulls all translations associated with the messages and validators domains for the en locale.
Local translations for the specified domains and locale are deleted if they're not present on the provider and overwritten if it's the case.
Local translations for others domains and locales are ignored.

Options:
--forceOverride existing translations with provider ones (it will delete not synchronized messages).
--intl-icuAssociated to --force option, it will write messages in "%domain%+intl-icu.%locale%.xlf" files.
--domainsSpecify the domains to pull.
--localesSpecify the locales to pull.
--formatOverride the default output format.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

option.help: Override existing translations with provider ones (it will delete not synchronized messages).

option.name: --intl-icu
option.help: Associated to --force option, it will write messages in "%domain%+intl-icu.%locale%.xlf" files.

command.name: translation:push
command.help:
The translation:push command pushes translations to the given provider. Only new
translations are pushed, existing ones are not overwritten.

You can overwrite existing translations by using the --force flag:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console translation:push --force provider

You can delete provider translations which are not present locally by using the --delete-missing flag:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console translation:push --delete-missing provider

Full example:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console translation:push provider --force --delete-missing --domains=messages,validators --locales=en

This command pushes all translations associated with the messages and validators domains for the en locale.
Provider translations for the specified domains and locale are deleted if they're not present locally and overwritten if it's the case.
Provider translations for others domains and locales are ignored.

Options:
--forceOverride existing translations with local ones (it will delete not synchronized messages).
--delete-missingDelete translations available on provider but not locally.
--domainsSpecify the domains to push.
--localesSpecify the locales to push.
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.

option.help: Override existing translations with local ones (it will delete not synchronized messages).

option.name: --delete-missing
option.help: Delete translations available on provider but not locally.

command.name: translation:update
command.help:
The translation:update command extracts translation strings from templates
of a given bundle or the default translations directory. It can display them or merge
the new ones into the translation files.

When new translation strings are found it can automatically add a prefix to the translation
message.

Example running against a Bundle (AcmeBundle)

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console translation:update --dump-messages en AcmeBundle
php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console translation:update --force --prefix="new_" fr AcmeBundle

Example running against default messages directory

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console translation:update --dump-messages en
php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console translation:update --force --prefix="new_" fr

You can sort the output with the --sort flag:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console translation:update --dump-messages --sort=asc en AcmeBundle
php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console translation:update --dump-messages --sort=desc fr

You can dump a tree-like structure using the yaml format with --as-tree flag:

php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console translation:update --force --format=yaml --as-tree=3 en AcmeBundle
php /home/devuser/PhpstormProjects/untitled/bin/console translation:update --force --format=yaml --sort=asc --as-tree=3 fr


Options:
--prefixOverride the default prefix
--output-formatOverride the default output format (deprecated)
--formatOverride the default output format
--dump-messagesShould the messages be dumped in the console
--forceShould the update be done
--cleanShould clean not found messages
--domainSpecify the domain to update
--xliff-versionOverride the default xliff version (deprecated)
--sortReturn list of messages sorted alphabetically
--as-treeDump the messages as a tree-like structure: The given value defines the level where to switch to inline YAML
--siteaccessSiteAccess to use for operations. If not provided, default siteaccess will be used
--help(-h)Display help for the given command. When no command is given display help for the list command
--quiet(-q)Do not output any message
--verbose(-v)Increase the verbosity of messages: 1 for normal output, 2 for more verbose output and 3 for debug
--version(-V)Display this application version
--ansiForce (or disable --no-ansi) ANSI output
--no-ansiNegate the "--ansi" option
--no-interaction(-n)Do not ask any interactive question
--env(-e)The Environment name.
--no-debugSwitch off debug mode.
